F. Small, white, night-blooming flowers

G. Flowers producing large amounts of nectar with low sugar concentration

H. Flowers with spiky petals and deep tubes

J. Nectar with high sugar concentration produced in limited amounts

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Which of the following adaptations would limit pollination by bees and promote hummingbird pollination?

A. Flowers with a narrow opening that only small insects can access

B. Pendant (hanging) red-colored flowers

C. Modified petals to provide a landing space

D. Flowers with a strong sweet fragrance

E. Bright blue flowers that open in the early morning

F. Small, white, night-blooming flowers

G. Flowers producing large amounts of nectar with low sugar concentration

H. Flowers with spiky petals and deep tubes

I. Patterns of ultraviolet color on the petals

J. Nectar with high sugar concentration produced in limited amounts

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Narrow opening for small insects—this seems like something bees would use. If the opening is too narrow for them, maybe they won't enter, limiting pollination. But does it help hummingbirds? Probably not much because hummingbirds don't depend on bee access. B. Pendant flowers—they hang down from trees or other plants. Maybe less than C because hummingbirds don't rely on petal placement. D. Large nectar with low sugar—bees love nectar with more sugar because they're easier to capture. Low sugar might make it harder for bees, but hummingbirds prefer sweet nectar anyway. So this might reduce bee access but not necessarily promote hummingbird pollination. E. Bright blue flowers—maybe appealing to hummingbirds, but do they interfere with bees' access? It depends on whether the blue color makes it hard for bees to get in or out. I'm not certain about this one. F. Small, white flowers—perhaps making them more attractive to hummingbirds. They might compete with others for nectar, but maybe not hinder bees.
